s1.title: Starting Cactus tests
s1.p: The Cactus tests are started using a JUnit Test Runner. There are several configurations for executing these test runners :

ul.li: From Ant, by using the <junit> task
From the java command line, calling the main() method of a Test Runner.
From an IDE or any tool providing a JUnit integration plugin.
From a browser, by using the Cactus Servlet Test Runner, which is a special JUnit Test Runner.

s1.note: This section only applies for Cactus 1.4 and greater.

s2.title: Step 1 : Setting up the classpath
s2.p: In order to run Cactus tests from a browser you need to have a webapp containing your classes to test and your test classes. In addition, both Cactus client side and server side jar classes must be able to be loaded from your webapp (i.e located in your WEB-INF/lib directory or in a location available through your container Context class loader (refer to your container documentation).
s2.note: Refer to the Classpath Howto guide for the exact list of jars.

s2.title: Step 2 : Mapping the Cactus Servlet Test Runner
s2.p: Then, in addition to the Cactus redirectors that you have mapped in your web.xml (see the Configuration howto), you also need to map the Cactus Servlet Test Runner, as follows :

s2.title: Step 3 : cactus.properties
s2.p: Lastly, you need to ensure you have put your cactus.properties file in your webapp WEB-INF/classes directory.

s2.title: Step 4 : Executing the tests
s2.p: Open a browser and type http://server:port/mywebapp/ServletTestRunner?suite=mytestcase where :

ul.li: server:port is the name of your server machine and port on which your container is running
mywebapp is the name of your webapp (usually the name of your war file)
mytestcase is the fully qualified name (i.e. with packages) of your TestCase class containing a suite() method listing all the tests, in standard JUnit fashion.

Ok, that's nice ... But what if I want HTML instead of XML ? Don't worry there is a solution. Grab the following stylesheet used to format JUnitReport Ant task results and drop it in your webapp and name it junit-noframes.xsl (in the root directory for example). Then, open a browser and type http://server:port/mywebapp/ServletTestRunner?suite=mytestcase&xsl=junit-noframes.xsl. You should see the following :
s2.note: This will work with Internet Explorer as the XSL transformation is performed on the client side (i.e by the browser). I'm not sure about other browsers.
